title:
Unifying design-based and model-based sampling theory -- some
  suggestions to clear the cobwebs
abstract:
This paper gives a holistic overview of both the design-based and model-based
paradigms for sampling theory. Both methods are presented within a unified
framework with a simple consistent notation, and the differences in the two
paradigms are explained within this common framework. We examine the different
definitions of the "population variance" within the two paradigms and examine
the use of Bessel's correction for a population variance. We critique some
messy aspects of the presentation of the design-based paradigm and implore
readers to avoid the standard presentation of this framework in favour of a
more explicit presentation that includes explicit conditioning in probability
statements. We also discuss a number of confusions that arise from the standard
presentation of the design-based paradigm and argue that Bessel's correction
should be applied to the population variance.
